title: What is an object-oriented paradigm and what are the main concepts of OOP?
subject: OOPS
answer: The object-oriented paradigm organizes programs around objects instead of functions. The main OOP concepts are: Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism and Abstraction.

title: Difference between object-oriented and object-based languages
subject: OOPS
answer: Object-oriented languages support inheritance, abstraction and polymorphism. Object-based languages only support objects and encapsulation. Examples: Java, C# → OOP. JavaScript, VB → object-based.

title: What is a Class?
subject: OOPS
answer: A class is a blueprint used to create objects. It contains fields, methods, constructors and blocks representing common properties and behavior.

title: What is an Object?
subject: OOPS
answer: An object is an instance of a class. It represents real-world entities and contains state (variables) and behavior (methods).

title: Ways to create objects in Java
subject: OOPS
answer: Objects can be created using: new keyword, Class.newInstance(), Constructor.newInstance(), clone(), and deserialization.

title: Difference between new and newInstance()
subject: OOPS
answer: new creates objects at compile-time with type known. newInstance() creates objects at runtime using reflection and may throw exceptions.

title: Static vs Instance methods
subject: OOPS
answer: Static methods belong to class, called without object, cannot use this, cannot be overridden. Instance methods belong to objects and can access instance data.

title: What is this keyword?
subject: OOPS
answer: this refers to the current object and is used to access current class members and resolve name conflicts.

title: Advantages and disadvantages of cloning
subject: OOPS
answer: Advantages: real copy, prototype pattern, faster. Disadvantages: requires Cloneable, shallow copy by default, complex for deep copy.

title: Shallow vs Deep cloning
subject: OOPS
answer: Shallow copy only copies top-level object and shares nested references. Deep copy duplicates entire object graph independently.

title: What are access specifiers?
subject: OOPS
answer: Access specifiers control visibility. Types: public, private, protected, default.

title: Default value of object reference instance variable
subject: OOPS
answer: The default value is null.

title: What is a constructor?
subject: OOPS
answer: Constructor initializes objects. Same name as class, no return type, called automatically, may be overloaded.

title: Types of constructors
subject: OOPS
answer: Types: Default, Parameterized, Copy constructor, Private constructor.

title: What if class has no constructor?
subject: OOPS
answer: Compiler provides a default no-argument constructor automatically.

title: Purpose of default constructor
subject: OOPS
answer: Initializes object with default values when no constructor is defined.

title: Where to use private constructor?
subject: OOPS
answer: Used to prevent object creation from outside. Commonly used in Singleton and utility classes.

title: Constructor vs Method
subject: OOPS
answer: Constructor creates object, no return type, called automatically. Method performs operation, has return type, called manually.

title: What is Encapsulation?
subject: OOPS
answer: Encapsulation binds data and methods together inside a class and hides internal implementation using private fields.

title: Advantages of Encapsulation
subject: OOPS
answer: Provides data hiding, flexibility, reusability and easier testing.

title: How to implement Encapsulation?
subject: OOPS
answer: Declare variables private and provide public getter and setter methods.

title: Use of getters and setters
subject: OOPS
answer: Getters read private data safely. Setters modify private data with validation control.

title: What is Inheritance?
subject: OOPS
answer: Inheritance allows one class to acquire properties and behavior of another class, enabling reusability.

title: Types of Inheritance
subject: OOPS
answer: Single, Multilevel, Hierarchical. Java supports multiple inheritance only through interfaces.

title: Multiple inheritance in Java
subject: OOPS
answer: Java does not support multiple inheritance using classes, but supports it via interfaces to avoid ambiguity.

title: Limitations of Inheritance
subject: OOPS
answer: Overuse may cause tight coupling, complexity and error-prone overriding.

title: What is IS-A relationship?
subject: OOPS
answer: IS-A represents inheritance (e.g., Dog IS-A Animal).

title: What is HAS-A relationship?
subject: OOPS
answer: HAS-A represents aggregation or composition (e.g., Car HAS-A Engine).

title: What is Aggregation?
subject: OOPS
answer: Aggregation is a weak HAS-A relation where child can exist independently of parent.

title: What is Association?
subject: OOPS
answer: Association represents a relationship between two independent classes using objects.

title: What is Composition?
subject: OOPS
answer: Composition is strong HAS-A relationship where child cannot exist without parent.

title: What is Polymorphism?
subject: OOPS
answer: Polymorphism means one thing with many forms. Same method behaves differently based on object type.

title: Types of Polymorphism
subject: OOPS
answer: Compile-time (method overloading) and Runtime (method overriding).

title: Compile-time Polymorphism
subject: OOPS
answer: Achieved using method overloading where same method name has different signatures.

title: Runtime Polymorphism
subject: OOPS
answer: Achieved through method overriding. Method call is resolved at runtime based on object.

title: Method overloading vs overriding
subject: OOPS
answer: Overloading: same method name, different parameters, compile-time. Overriding: subclass changes parent method, runtime.

title: Can static methods be overridden?
subject: OOPS
answer: No. Static methods belong to class, not object. They can only be hidden.

title: Changing scope while overriding
subject: OOPS
answer: Scope can be same or wider but not more restrictive.

title: What is Abstraction?
subject: OOPS
answer: Abstraction hides internal implementation and shows only essential features.

title: Ways to achieve Abstraction
subject: OOPS
answer: Using abstract classes and interfaces.

title: What is Abstract class?
subject: OOPS
answer: A class declared abstract cannot be instantiated. It may contain abstract and non-abstract methods.

title: What is an Interface?
subject: OOPS
answer: Interface defines contract containing abstract methods and constants. Classes implementing it must define behavior.

title: Features of Interfaces
subject: OOPS
answer: Support total abstraction, multiple inheritance, loose coupling, and reusable design.

title: What is Marker Interface?
subject: OOPS
answer: Empty interface with no methods, used to provide metadata to JVM. Examples: Serializable, Cloneable.

title: Abstract class vs Interface
subject: OOPS
answer: Abstract class can have state and mixed methods. Interface defines behavior contract, supports multiple inheritance, all members public by default.
